name: Mid to Senior 1
summary: S1 engineers are expected to improve the performance of those around them. This could be through additional official responsibilities such as line managing or tech leading, or through unofficial means such as mentoring or regular pairing. S1 engineers should be able to tackle more complicated technical problems, and explain and justify their approaches to their team. We expect S1 engineers to pick up work outside of their delivery team and manage that work effectively against their delivery team’s priorities.

competencies.summary: Implements observability and monitoring when building a solution
Evaluates third-party software to use in projects
examples: Can choose between similar Node libraries evaluating code quality, ease of integration, future maintenance, and security concerns
May be involved in evaluating paid-for third party supplier code

competencies.summary: Leads on fixing production issues
Understands the security attack vectors for their area of technology and mitigates against them
examples: Uses Snyk.io on projects
Sanitises user input to mitigate against XSS attacks

competencies.summary: Manages technical debt in projects, understands consequences of technical debt vs the cost of fixing it and acts accordingly
Takes responsibility for code quality by keeping the quality high and encouraging others in the team to do the same
Independently debugs bugs regardless of origin
Builds software or services considering resilience, performance and failure modes
Debugs and fixes complex issues
Keeps up with industry trends
examples: Attends meet-ups or conferences
Reads blog posts about technology
Follows industry leaders on twitter
Shares industry relevant content/links with team members that may be interested

competencies.summary: Chooses the appropriate tool, technology or software for a task
examples: If starting a new project, uses tools already understood by the team unless there is an agreed good reason to change

competencies.summary: Maintains documentation on the systems they work on, makes it easy for future engineers to interact with systems and code
Provides feedback for complex features
examples: Gives detailed empathetic feedback in pull requests

competencies.summary: Has worked with in or with another team
examples: Has done a three month secondment with Operations and Reliability
Has done a bootcamp with another team

competencies.summary: Communicates technical concepts to non-technical people clearly
Runs meetings with clear agendas and outcomes
Shares knowledge with others internally
examples: Gives a workshop on Git
Pairs on a feature with a more junior colleague
Runs a regular 101 session for the rest of the business
More informal knowledge sharing through mentorship

competencies.summary: Prioritises technical work for the team (usually with others)
Translates requirements into deliverable units of work
Communicates team/work's status upwards to a Principal or Technical Director
Does not unnecessarily duplicate work of other teams
Moves blockers to enable more junior engineers to work
examples: Reviews pull requests
Suggests someone to talk to eg “[X] knows the most about [technology Y], you could ask them”

competencies.summary: Tackles simple cross team technical issues
examples: Notices a tool used by lots of teams has broken, identifies the problem and fixes

competencies.summary: Understands and considers other teams' needs
examples: Attends cross team meetings

competencies.summary: Improves flow of delivery
Demonstrates awareness of how their work (or team) relates to the rest of the FT
Influences a community of practice
examples: Is an active member of a Guild
Answers questions in the #engineering Slack channel

competencies.summary: Is an ambassador for their team across FT technology and colleagues in the rest of the business
Has responsibility for others’ development through mentoring or line management
Contributes to hiring process
examples: Participates in hiring panels or technical interviews
Attends recruitment events

competencies.summary: Shows Technical leadership
examples: Is a tech lead
Runs, or is on the organising team for a Guild
Leads on large features or stories
